Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 12:48AM cheery wrote: The controversies/concerns from the MD Anderson and many other studies for local surgery for mets is that these patients have been cherry picked, meaning they are the ones likely to have the best outcome, surgery or not. Young and healthy with single met.  The statistics on the various reports I've seen are about 47- 60% 5-year overall survival or disease-free progression. You've probably seen these older reports but thought I'd still post it in case anyone else is interested.  http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/102/7/456.full http://www.medpagetoday.com/MeetingCoverage/ASCOGI/24490 It is widely acknowledged that ER/PR+ ladies have the best prognosis and the hormonal therapy can keep the disease stable for many years. Kathy Rich (19+ yrs) and Marybe (>10 years) have had great success with hormonal therapies. Ideally, of course, it would be even better if we can keep our disease further in check with curative surgical options too. I do believe your active approach and ER/PR+ status will help you do well:) hope you'll have a good discussion with the 2nd opinion and get your questions answered.
Posts.Title: Who had mets in liver only or liver first? curveball curveball

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2013 10:13PM cheery wrote: Curveball  I'd responded to your other posts but I'm writing again as I've just had seen a liver surgeon yesterday. I'm almost 5 years out with liver met.  Indeed, BC tends to travel to the bones as the first site of mets rather liver or lungs. I've read that only 5-10% of BC travels to liver as the first site and as a single or two mets. This may be different for HER2+ BC as the liver met tends to be more common than bones, since HER2+ is much more aggressive.  The liver surgeon has said that the ideal person to have liver resection would be someone who was diagnosed at an earlier stage and has been stable for 10-20 years when a solitary or two liver met occured. He would then consider the person good for curative liver resection. I'm not a good candidate for liver resection, as I've just been told, as I was Stage IV from the get-go with a single liver met. Notwithstanding the fact that I was NED for the 4 years before this liver met recurred.  Liver surgeons are reluctant to operate on BC as it's considered a systemic disease. For BC to have travelled to liver, the assumption is that it'd have to bypass the bones and lungs (more common areas of BC mets) to the liver, where the blood supply is rich. Hence, the notion that liver mets are more aggressive.  This is different from colon colon as the liver is often the first site of mets. Hence, it is believed that the disease is still early and can be effectively "controlled/eliminated" with liver resection/cyberknife. Now the liver surgeon has said that if I were to insist, he can do the liver resection for me but he's pretty confident another liver met can pop up within 1 week of my surgery. He's one of the top liver surgeons in the region and I tend to believe he's saying this based on his experience.    The above said, the liver surgeon has said that if my liver met recurrence (now 2 instead of one), can be effectively controlled/eliminated by chemo/HER2+ agents in the next 3-6 months, I can still see him again for further discussion. I've read they need to see stability/NED in the liver region due to the downtime for liver surgery.  I can understand your anxiety and frustration as I've been living with this liver met for the past 5 years hoping to get a liver resection. I continue to live in hope for a liver resection and I think you should insist on a seeing liver specialist soonest to get a better feel of your possiblity of a liver resection. If anything, it'll address your concerns once and for all and I believe knowledge helps a lot in this crap disease.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Who had mets in liver only or liver first? curveball curveball

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2012 12:56PM cheery wrote: My doc does not use PET scans. For my liver met, he monitors with CT scan and MRI. In fact, one doc has said the MRI is the most definitive scan for the liver. For my initial liver met diagnosis and subsequent liver met recurrence, I've seen the mass on the CT scans each time.  Both times liver enzymes have remained normal, only tumour markers jumped. The tumour markers may be an indication if there is an upward trend over 2-3 months.  So just to be sure, I would get a CT scan/MRI if it were me.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 02:52AM cheery wrote: So sorry for the trauma that you're going through. Your mum is certainly a fighter and I hope she'll feel much better after the radiation therapy.  Some ladies here swear by L-Glutamine for neuropathy. I've tried it myself and I think it works:p I believe Vit B should work too but I've never tried it.  I've read that Affinitor (not chemo) may work well with hormonal therapy to reverse ER/PR resistance. Avastin, a controversial antibody, can possibly control the disease but it's no longer covered by insurance.  You've not mentioned what chemos your mum has had. I'm no doctor but off hand, both Taxol (similar to Taxotere) and Doxil/Adriamycin can offer long term control of the disease. I'm on Taxol now and latest scans have shown regression. Carboplatin is another chemo option. Ultimately, the best chemo is the one that your mum's body responds to but unfortunately, it is difficult to ascertain until she tries it out.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Mom stage IV, Gemzar didn't work, please give hope!! gapeach524 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 08:42AM - edited Aug 20, 2012 08:44AM by cheery Hi HER2 Sorry that you have to be here. I don't have brain or lung mets but I'm HER2+. Herceptin is known to have an impact on the heart, esp with Adriamycin. If she has heart issues, you can check with the onco if Herceptin is still suitable. Low ejection fraction caused by Herceptin is reversible once you stop it. But there could unforseen circumstances that we have to be careful about, if your mum has heart issues.  I'm not aware that Tykerb has any effect on the heart. Tykerb and Xeloda is a combination that is believed to cross the blood brain barrier. So there is a possiblity for your mum to have chemo with HER2 agent.  For mets, sometimes it is good to consider re-biopsying the mets (newly diagnosed) as the ER/PR/HER2 receptors may have changed and it will affect the treatment therapies. A biopsy, however, is invasive so you'll have to balance that.  For HER2+ brain mets, there is a treatment called intrathecal Herceptin. I'm not sure if it's relevant for your mum's condition. Link below for your reading:- her2support.org/vbulletin/show... I'm not a doctor so please check the doctor for the best treatment option for your mum.  All the best to you and your mum.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2013 01:55AM cheery wrote: Doctors are reluctant to do stem cell transplant as it can be potentially dangerous given the very high dose of chemotherapy and then re-introduction of new cells into the body. A lot depends on whether your body can take the hit and recover on its own - it is a big risk, but hey no risk, no gain. You will notice that these ladies have all continued their hormonal therapy, so the big question is - would these ladies have continued to do well even without the stem cell transplant (as it is also known as)? Marybe was a long time survivor without the stem cell transplant or dietary constraints. Like 2 doctors told me, these are the ones that lived to tell the tale but for the many others who did not, they wouldn't be here to tell you it didn't work. That said, there has been renewed interest in stem cell transplant. I would definitely jump onto it once my doctor deems it a viable option. I've attached the 2011 Stanford review in case you're interested. med.stanford.edu/ism/2011/july... www.bbmt.org/article/S1083-879...

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 09:44AM - edited Nov 15, 2012 09:53AM by cheery I didn't have aggressive treatment from the start. I was already NED by the time I'd my mastectomy 2 years after initial Stage IV diagnosis. I'm 4.5 years out, by the way Typically, for Stage IV, the conventional thinking is to control the disease and alleviate any symptoms. Doctors believe that as the disease is systemic, there is no point in treating the disease "aggressively" by putting the patients through more pain from surgery of any sort unless critical.  In recent years, however, there has been a shift in thinking and from observational studies that perhaps Stage IV can benefit from surgery too. Hence, they do allow a certain segment of Stage IV ladies to undergo surgery to improve prognosis. The big question is, do these Stage IV ladies do well due to the surgery/aggressive treatment or was it because they had been cherry picked in the first place with best chances of long term survival to undergo the surgery/aggressive treatment?  That said, I believe everyone should be given the choice of surgery as there is psychological benefit to removing the tumours, whether it's in the breast or elsewhere. Of course, the tumour load reduction is a major benefit too

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 01:33PM cheery wrote: It's scary that the receptor status changes all the time. Ironically, I'm happy to be HER2+ at the moment.  At diagnosis (Stage IV out of the gate), I was biopsied ER/PR+ in my primary breast tumour. No biopsy was done on my liver spot. After neo-adjuvant chemo, the liver met resolved completely and I had a mastectomy. The pathology of breast tumour was ER/PR-. The doctors believed that I've always been ER/PR- (hence, no hormonal treatment) given the fact that the BC went straight to liver and not bone. They felt that the biopsy was not accurate. Only 1 doc I saw recently when my doc was on leave said she thinks I'm still ER/PR+. Well, who knows the real story..

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2013 02:15PM cheery wrote: Hi Deb  So sorry you'd to join us. I'm not triple negative but would like to chime in with what I've read that might be effective for TNBC.  Parp inhibitors (eg. Veliparib/ABT-888) can be very effective in some TNBC ladies and some others have chemo with targeted therapy like avastin. I'm not sure if there is any clinical trial in NZ for these agents as they can improve the effectiveness of chemos.  There are many other chemos that you've not mentioned, eg. Adriamycin, Xeloda, Halaven and Ixempra. I'm not sure why your oncologist has suggested hospice unless you no longer wish to do any more chemos and would prefer to try the alternative treatment options.  Perhaps you might want to seek a second opinion from another oncologist?  Take care and best regards.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2014 09:44PM cheery wrote: Just to add to the above,  My radiation oncologist told me that RFA is considered invasive while SBRT is not. The tumour size should ideally be 3cm and below for optimal results. There is no downtime from both procedures, as compared to a liver resection. I'd explored these options with the relevant surgeons previously for my liver met.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: Options for Liver Mets - RFA vs. SBRT morningcoffee tcallegan

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2012 11:42PM - edited Nov 16, 2012 11:44PM by cheery SophieJean Thank you for putting it so clearly, as always.  Being HER2+, I have very aggressive cancer. It came back with a resounding 4.5cm after clean scans 3 months before.  And yes, that's why after 2 months of chemo, it's now shrunk down to 2.1cm. Chemo is more effective for the fast replicating (and aggressive) HER2+ cells.  I'm still gunning for that liver resection as I see it as my only chance of getting a shot at NED for a longer period of time. When I was NED for the last 3 years, I had sought opinions from at least 6 oncos who said that I should not go for the liver resection. Now, every onco just bows his head and say, go ahead now that it's back again.. Of course, it's too late now..I can't help but wonder what if I'd gone for the liver resection 3 years ago.. What I'm trying to say is, please find out more about every possible treatment out there and fight for your chance to get that treatment as we don't want to look back and wonder if we'd done all that we can..

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2013 10:53AM cheery wrote: I didn't do Taxol but Navelbine.  When I'd a recurrence in my liver recently, I'd Navelbine again. Didn't feel any different from 8 months before. But I've since switched to Taxol as I wasn't happy with Navelbine. It kept the disease stable but we didn't get any shrinkage. I got nervous and asked my onc to change to Taxol and Carboplatin, together with Herceptin. With Taxol and Carbo, I've started to see shrinkage. So the side effects were worth it.  My doctor said he's seen many ladies who do Taxol on a long term basis and they get very good control out of it. Hope Taxol will be effective for us both:)

They were worried about liver toxicity and failure. So they started on Herceptin only. She'd come back weeks later to say her sister can now walk around and can now receive chemo. Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2014 12:45AM cheery wrote: @woodylb  Not my intention to go OT but thought I'd respond to your query.  Briefly, chemo is systemic treatment targeted at the whole body, including both bone and liver mets. Bone mets are generally deemed to be slow growing while liver mets are considered more aggressive in nature. As such, your doc wants to quickly hit the liver mets hard with Carbo/Gemzar. This is a very strong chemo combo as each chemo on its own can be very hard on the blood counts. Both are known to be effective on liver mets.  You might want to start a new thread to get more feedback, otherwise there are several threads in Triple Negative. I've linked one for your reading.  Carbo/Gemzar Hope this helps.

Penny, hope all goes smoothly with your treatment tomorrow. Ronnie, I too have a fatty liver. And heck, I still drink a fair bit (up to 1/3 of a bottle consecutively on some nights) when I'm not having chemo! lol..thankfully my liver enzymes are still normal;) the only times when my liver enzymes went out of whack is when I'd liver met progression and some liver injury due to drug interaction between TCM and chemo. I also think the chemo affects our liver more than alcohol, unless one is a serious alcoholic. My doc did give me the go-ahead and he said he didn't think I was drinking that much:) best news ever!! lol.. I'm sharing this given the hols season and everyone loves a little drink during the festive times:) happy hols everyone!

Posts.Title: Brain Fart-help Please lilylady lilylady

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2014 10:31AM - edited Jul 15, 2014 12:34PM by cheery My doctor uses the term remission. The scans are reported as NED. I think it's used interchangeably but remission appears to be an older term.  Having fallen in and out of NED, I can understand the hope of looking forward to NED and the extrapolation that one may belong to that 1-3% that lives a normal lifespan (my doctor quoted 1-3%). So, while I'm definitely more realistic now about a cure for Stage IV BC, I'll always remember Kathleen Rich, who lived 19+ years with BC mets. I could be wrong (as I haven't read her book though) but I don't think she'd achieved NED. So, it's great encouragement for everyone that you can still hope to live a long life without achieving NED.  I think the research articles about curing stage IV BC is also spurring the hope factor. Personally, I don't think hope is bad but ultimately, we have to realise that in reality, these people are far and few as the cure for cancer remains elusive.

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2013 12:41AM cheery wrote: Anko  More recently, some doctors believe that removal of primary tumour in the breast will reduce the tumour load and possibly, kill off the BC stem cells. There has been research that patients who remove the primary tumours do better in the long run, but there is argument to that research as they'd cherry picked the candidates that will do well anyway (surgery or not).  My breast surgeon has told me that primary tumours do not respond well to chemo as they're slow growing unlike mets, which is very fast growing.  For me, it was a psychological effect as I just wanted the ticking time bomb of my body.  The surgery was pain-free in my case. I was in and out of the hospital in 3 days. Recovery took about a month with a bit of drainage required.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 08:31PM cheery wrote: Sweetbean  So sorry to hear about your friend. It does sound like she's got good family and friend support thoough:) Cisplatin is a platinum drug and I've read that platinum drugs can be very effective for TN and BRCA related BC. It's in the same family as Carboplatin. I'm having Carboplatin as part of my TCH regime. My doc told me it can be hard on the white blood cells and I've had to skip one chemo after 3 cycles. Overall it is doable with the usual chemo side effects.   Carboplatin can cause allergic reactions after several infusions. But this should be easily resolved by slower drip and extra decadron. The nurses would be closely monitoring for such reactions as it's fairly common.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: My friend is now Stage IV and about to start Cisplatin sweetbean sweetbean

Posts.Content: May 27, 2013 02:00AM cheery wrote: Hey..sorry to hear about this but fret not..there are still quite a few combos that you can try..off hand, the following:- 1) TDM1 /Kadcyla 2) Perjeta, Herceptin & Taxol 3) Herceptin & Tykerb with chemo  4) Herceptin, Tykerb and Avastin and chemo  You'll notice some are 2 HER2+ agents combos as there is research that the double agents or even triple agents actually work synergistically together.  I'm not sure if you've had a chance to do a liver biopsy to see if it's also ER/PR- and HER2+ as sometimes it does not have the same pathology as the primary tumour. Just a suggestion. I know it's very hard dealing with progression but please try to look forward to the next treatment combo as it may very well put you to stability/NED. Unfortunately no one can tell which of the combos can help you definitively until you've tried it..  So, I'm sure your onco still has lots in his arsenal and will recommend you something suitable. It will get better when you begin the next treatment. Please try to hang in there.
